column2: BAT JARVIS

column2: Billy Windsor lived in a single room on East Fourteenth Street. Space in New York is valuable, and the average bachelor's apartments consist of one room with a bathroom opening off it. During the daytime this one room loses all traces of being used for sleeping purposes at night.
column3: Billy Windsor lived in a single room on East Fourteenth Street. Space in New York is valuable, and the average bachelor's apartments consist of one room with a bathroom opening off it. During the daytime this one room loses all traces of being used for sleeping purposes at night.

column2: Billy Windsor's room was very much like a public-school study.
column3: Billy Windsor's room was very much like a public school study.

column2: Along one wall ran a settee.
column3: Along one wall ran a settee.

column2: At night this became a bed; but in the daytime it was a settee and nothing but a settee.
column3: At night this became a bed; but in the daytime it was a settee and nothing but a settee.

column2: There was no space for a great deal of furniture.
column3: There was no space for a great deal of furniture.

column2: There was one rocking-chair, two ordinary chairs, a table, a book-stand, a typewriter--nobody uses pens in New York--and on the walls a mixed collection of photographs, drawings, knives, and skins, relics of their owner's prairie days.
column3: There was one rocking chair, two ordinary chairs, a table, a book stand, a typewriter-nobody uses pens in New York-and on the walls a mixed collection of photographs, drawings, knives, and skins, relics of their owner's prairie days.

column3: Over the door was the head of a young bear.

column2: Billy's first act on arriving in this sanctum was to release the cat, which, having moved restlessly about for some moments, finally came to the conclusion that there was no means of getting out, and settled itself on a corner of the settee.
column3: Billy's first act on arriving in this sanctum was to release the cat, which, having moved restlessly about for some moments, finally came to the conclusion that there was no means of getting out, and settled itself on a corner of the settee.

column2: Mike took one of the ordinary chairs; and Billy Windsor, planting himself in the rocker, began to rock rhythmically to and fro, a performance which he kept up untiringly all the time.

column2: Psmith had picked up one of the papers when there came a shuffling of feet in the passage outside, followed by a knock upon the door. The next moment there appeared in the doorway a short, stout young man.

column2: There was an indescribable air of toughness about him, partly due to the fact that he wore his hair in a well-oiled fringe almost down to his eyebrows, which gave him the appearance of having no forehead at all.

column3: Not, in short, the sort of man you would have picked out on sight as a model citizen.

column3: His entrance was marked by a curious sibilant sound, which, on acquaintance, proved to be a whistled tune.

column2: I am Psmith."

column2: As he looked round the room, his eye fell on the cat.

column2: Are you Bat Jarvis? asked Windsor with interest.
column3: Are you Bat Jarvis? asked Windsor with interest.

column2: Sure, said the visitor, not without a touch of complacency, as of a monarch abandoning his incognito.

column2: For Mr. Jarvis was a celebrity.
column3: For mr Jarvis was a celebrity.

column2: By profession he was a dealer in animals, birds, and snakes.
column3: By profession he was a dealer in animals, birds, and snakes.

column2: He had a fancier's shop in Groome street, in the heart of the Bowery.
column3: He had a fancier's shop in Groome street, in the heart of the Bowery.

column2: This was on the ground-floor.
column3: This was on the ground floor.

column2: His living abode was in the upper story of that house, and it was there that he kept the twenty-three cats whose necks were adorned with leather collars, and whose numbers had so recently been reduced to twenty-two.
column3: His living abode was in the upper story of that house, and it was there that he kept the twenty three cats whose necks were adorned with leather collars, and whose numbers had so recently been reduced to twenty two.

column2: But it was not the fact that he possessed twenty-three cats with leather collars that made Mr. Jarvis a celebrity.
column3: But it was not the fact that he possessed twenty three cats with leather collars that made mr Jarvis a celebrity.

column2: A man may win a purely local reputation, if only for eccentricity, by such means.

column2: But Mr. Jarvis's reputation was far from being purely local.
column3: But mr Jarvis's reputation was far from being purely local.

column2: Broadway knew him, and the Tenderloin.

column2: Tammany Hall knew him.

column2: Long Island City knew him.

column2: In the underworld of New York his name was a by-word.
column3: In the underworld of New York his name was a by word.

column2: For Bat Jarvis was the leader of the famous Groome Street Gang, the most noted of all New York's collections of Apaches.
column3: For Bat Jarvis was the leader of the famous Groome Street Gang, the most noted of all New York's collections of Apaches.

column2: More, he was the founder and originator of it.

column2: In Groome Street in those days there had been a dance-hall, named the Shamrock and presided over by one Maginnis, an Irishman and a friend of Bat's.
column3: In Groome Street in those days there had been a dance hall, named the Shamrock and presided over by one Maginnis, an Irishman and a friend of Bat's.

column2: At the Shamrock nightly dances were given and well attended by the youth of the neighbourhood at ten cents a head.
column3: At the Shamrock nightly dances were given and well attended by the youth of the neighbourhood at ten cents a head.

column2: All might have been well, had it not been for certain other youths of the neighbourhood who did not dance and so had to seek other means of getting rid of their surplus energy.

column2: For he, with his followers, were of use to the politicians.

column2: The New York gangs, and especially the Groome Street Gang, have brought to a fine art the gentle practice of "repeating"; which, broadly speaking, is the art of voting a number of different times at different polling-stations on election days. A man who can vote, say, ten times in a single day for you, and who controls a great number of followers who are also prepared, if they like you, to vote ten times in a single day for you, is worth cultivating.
